title: The Study of Crystallization Kinetics and Chemical Changes in Ge4Sb4Te5 through Transmission Electron Microscope
content: Phase-change materials are currently being investigated for many important applications including phase-change memory [1]. The most studied alloy is Ge2Sb2Te5, which exists in several polymorphs such as a metastable face-centered-cubic structure (FCC) cubic at ∼150 °C and a stable hexagonal at ∼300 °C have been observed after heating the initially amorphous phase [2]. These structural changes happen at a very rapid pace and therefore capturing the dynamics of the processes is key to understand the corresponding functional behaviors such as electrical and optical properties [3-5]. For example, the degree of crystallinity is expected to influence the electrical resistivity in phase-change materials and therefore its quantification is important to correlate the electrical resistivity measurements. Moreover, investigation of concurrent chemical changes vis-à-vis structural modifications is another issue to address in this class of materials. Lower amorphous to crystalline transformation temperatures in Ge2Sb2Te5 is a drawback for their usage in high temperature applications. Ge-rich GST alloys are reported to possess higher crystallization temperatures accompanied with phase separation [6]. Moreover, chemical segregation has also been noted prior to crystallization events in these alloys [3,7,8]. In this paper, we present in-situ heating investigation of Ge4Sb4Te5 alloy (GST-445) thin film of thickness ∼30 nm deposited on Protochips inside TEM from room temperature to 400 °C. Studies on crystallization temperatures, phase evolutions and associated compositional changes have been carried out and results are compared with those of Ge2Sb2Te5 alloy. For examples, a sample was heated in steps of 25 °C from room temperature to 100 °C followed by in steps of 10 °C from 150 °C onwards. This sample was observed to remains amorphous up to 140 °C and the first sign of crystallization was observed at ∼150 °C when investigated by following selected area diffraction (SAD) patterns during heating inside the TEM. With further heating, growth of the initially nucleated grains has been observed. A representative SAD pattern and corresponding bright-field TEM image acquired at 180 °C is shown in Figure 1(a) and 1(b), respectively. The spotty rings (cf. Figure 1(a)) suggested the random nucleation and growth of crystals and could be indexed as those of FCC-Ge2Sb2Te5. Figure 2 shows the processed snapshots using custom written Python script of the in-situ acquired images by employing K3 IS camera at room temperature, 50 °C, 100 °C, and 140 °C during heating from room temperature to 140 °C inside the Titan. These images clearly indicates that domains of crystalline regions are observed even at room temperature in GST-445, which could not be detected in SAD diffraction patterns in Tecnai F30. Samples were examined for their structure and chemistry employing a FEI Tecnai F30 and Cs-corrected Titan ETEM. Morphological and structural evolutions were captured during heating inside the Titan equipped with a high-speed camera (K2/K3 IS) under low-dose conditions to minimize the beam induced changes in the samples. For chemical analysis STEM-EDS and STEM-EELS characterizations are performed [9].
